title: 105_s2545
content: The Medicare HMO Protection Act of 1998 allows for the evaluation and alteration of termination decisions. The Medicare HMO Protection Act of 1998 allows the Secretary to delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice organization's plan if it poses a serious risk to enrolled individuals' health. The Medicare HMO Protection Act of 1998 allows the Secretary to delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice organization's plan if it poses an imminent and serious risk to enrolled individuals' health or if the termination would significantly reduce available Medicare+Choice plans in the affected area. The Medicare HMO Protection Act of 1998 allows the Secretary to delay terminating Medicare+Choice plans in nearby areas to prevent financial losses. The Secretary can audit organization's books under section 1857(d) to make this determination. The Secretary can inspect organization's books under section 1857(d) to determine if Medicare+Choice plans should be terminated to prevent financial losses. The delay can be ended if an adequate provider network is established to provide equal insurance coverage. The Secretary can delay termination of Medicare+Choice plans if an adequate provider network is established to maintain equal insurance coverage. The Secretary and Medicare+Choice organization can negotiate a new contract to continue coverage without adversely affecting beneficiaries. SEC. 3. Extension of initial Medicare+Choice contract period to 3 years. Amends the Social Security Act to require contracts to have a term of at least 3 years. Effective for contracts entered into after the enactment of this Act. Section 1857(d)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to require Medicare+Choice organizations to provide written notice 120 days before contract termination, including alternative benefit options for enrolled individuals. The amended Social Security Act requires Medicare+Choice organizations to provide notice 120 days before contract termination, including alternative benefit options and contact information for local social service agencies. The amended Social Security Act requires Medicare+Choice organizations to provide notice of termination, including contact information for local social service agencies. This amendment applies to notices provided after the enactment of the Act.
